G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law implies into every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 19.proposition: The Boston Municipal Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 1, 19 and applicable jurisdictional statutes and rules because the amount in controversy is within the Court’s jurisdictional limits and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as the landlord, was responsible for providing and maintaining heat in the Premises in compliance with Massachusetts law and the State Sanitary Code, including 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., and in particular 105 CMR 410.200 (Minimum Heat in Habitable Rooms).

105 CMR 410.200.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as the landlord, was responsible for providing and maintaining heat in the Premises in compliance with Massachusetts law and the State Sanitary Code, including 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., and in particular 105 CMR 410.200 (Minimum Heat in Habitable Rooms).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A, 127B.proposition: The duty to provide adequate heat is a core component of maintaining habitable premises and of a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment. See 105 CMR 410.200; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A, 127B (authorizing adoption and enforcement of housing sanitary code standards, including heating requirements).

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Defendant John Mitchell is an individual who, on information and belief, owns and/or manages the residential rental property located at 123 Elm Street, Dorchester, Suffolk County, Massachusetts 02124 (the “Premises”), and is Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest on all sums awarded, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6C or other applicable law;

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law implies into every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly treats a covenant of quiet enjoyment as an implied term of the residential leases at issue and analyzes whether the landlords breached that implied covenant. The court repeatedly refers to the tenants’ "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment and treats it as a standard incident of the landlord‑tenant relationship under Massachusetts law. Although the case focuses on the scope and breach of the covenant, its reasoning presupposes and affirms that such an implied covenant exists in residential leases.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that significant or repeated violations of the State Sanitary Code or other serious conditions affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses State Sanitary Code violations and other unsanitary conditions and links them to both habitability and statutory quiet enjoyment. The court notes that the landlord’s duty under the implied warranty of habitability includes keeping the premises in conformity with the State Sanitary Code, and then holds that allowing repeated, preventable flooding in violation of that duty constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This directly supports the proposition that significant or repeated sanitary code violations or serious habitability defects can amount to unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code… Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries… Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code… provides that apartments must be watertight…. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 363.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that significant or repeated violations of the State Sanitary Code or other serious conditions affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 363.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion is focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations, not on the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment or "unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment." It discusses code violations as breaches of implied obligations tied to habitability and rent, not as constituting interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14 or similar doctrines. The text provided does not frame serious or repeated sanitary code violations in quiet‑enjoyment terms, so it does not directly support the specific proposition claimed.
*Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 363.relevant_excerpt: “The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally, (b) that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations, and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that significant or repeated violations of the State Sanitary Code or other serious conditions affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses what level of landlord fault is necessary for a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, not whether sanitary code or habitability conditions can constitute such a violation. While it cites earlier cases (Simon, Darmetko, Dorgan, Cruz) that involve serious habitability defects, this case itself neither reiterates nor focuses on the proposition that significant or repeated Sanitary Code violations constitute unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment; instead, it clarifies that at least negligent conduct and landlord notice are required, and that a bare statutory violation (lead paint strict liability) is not enough.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

*Hermida v. Archstone*, 826 F. Supp. 2d.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that significant or repeated violations of the State Sanitary Code or other serious conditions affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Hermida v. Archstone*, 826 F. Supp. 2d.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the Massachusetts Security Deposit Statute and whether an upfront ‘amenity use fee’ violates section 15B(1)(b). It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, nor habitability, the State Sanitary Code, or interference with quiet enjoyment based on code violations or serious conditions. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about sanitary code violations constituting unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Hermida v. Archstone*, 826 F. Supp. 2d.relevant_excerpt: The Security Deposit Statute is intended to afford protection to both the landlord and the tenant. It protects the landlord by allowing it to charge certain advances of money prior to the commencement of the tenancy; the statute also limits the up-front charges that the landlord legally can collect from the tenant in order to prevent unfair or deceptive charges. ... Because section 15B(1)(b) prohibits the landlord from charging up-front any amount in addition to those enumerated provisions, Archstone Reading exceeded the charges allowed by the Security Deposit Statute.

*Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc.*, 437 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that significant or repeated violations of the State Sanitary Code or other serious conditions affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc.*, 437 Mas.support_reasoning: The case is a commercial lease dispute about dependent covenants and constructive eviction, not a residential tenancy or State Sanitary Code matter. While it discusses constructive eviction and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, it does so in a commercial context and never refers to the State Sanitary Code, habitability, or repeated sanitary code violations as constituting unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about Massachusetts courts repeatedly holding that sanitary code or serious habitability violations can constitute such interference.
*Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc.*, 437 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. Where there is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the tenant may raise constructive eviction as a defense to an action to recover rent. ... However, not every act or failure to act on the part of the landlord that causes disruption to a tenant rises to the level of a constructive eviction."

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Massachusetts courts have further recognized that persistent failure to supply adequate heat or other essential utilities, particularly during winter months, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case deals with lack of heat and hot water, but exclusively in the context of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion never mentions, analyzes, or applies the covenant of quiet enjoyment as a basis for relief. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that persistent failure to supply adequate heat breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even though it recognizes such failures as material breaches of the warranty of habitability.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition... We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.

*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168.proposition: Massachusetts courts have further recognized that persistent failure to supply adequate heat or other essential utilities, particularly during winter months, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the implied warranty of habitability, damage calculations, and when damages begin to run based on the landlord’s knowledge or notice of defects. It does not address the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it specifically mention heat or essential utilities as a basis for such a covenant’s breach. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that persistent failure to supply adequate heat or utilities constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*McKenna v. Begin*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168.relevant_excerpt: “For the guidance of the trial court upon rehearing, damages are to be based upon the difference between the fair rental value of the premises as warranted to be habitable and the fair rental value of the premises in their defective condition. If it is shown that the defective conditions existed at the inception of the tenancy, damages shall be computed from that time. If the conditions are shown to have arisen during the tenancy, damages are to be computed from the time the landlord first knew or was notified of their existence.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have further recognized that persistent failure to supply adequate heat or other essential utilities, particularly during winter months, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a landlord’s statutory obligation under the State Sanitary Code to provide heat and hot water and holds that this obligation can only be shifted to the tenant via a written agreement. It does not analyze or even mention the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address whether persistent failure to provide heat or utilities constitutes a breach of that covenant. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’… The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”
